channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New Image of the Hong Kong Protests: ‘Umbrella Man’
item.description: A 12-foot figure of wooden blocks holding a bright yellow umbrella in its outstretched right hand was moved into the protest site in front of government headquarters, evoking the Goddess of Democracy sculpture installed by students in Tiananmen Square in 1989.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A new mascot for the pro-democracy movement in Hong Kong, dubbed Umbrella Man, emerged on Sunday night.

item.title: U.S. Airman Is Killed, 2 Others Are Missing, After Typhoon Hits Okinawa
item.description: The Americans were swept out to sea by the powerful storm that was headed toward Tokyo.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Afghanistan Reverses Expulsion of Times Reporter
item.description: Matthew Rosenberg, who was expelled from the country in August, will be allowed to return effective immediately, according to the Afghan attorney general’s office.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matthew Rosenberg, a New York Times correspondent, on his way to the Kabul airport in August.

item.title: International Education: A Bigger World of International Law
item.description: As courts and nongovernmental organizations look for wider geographical representation, smaller and newer law schools in Asia and Australia are moving to catch up.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: Protesters in Hong Kong Ease Sit-In at Government Headquarters
item.description: The consensus of democracy demonstrators remains elusive after the government set a Monday deadline for the police to ensure access to the complex.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Some protesters continued to occupy the streets outside the government house in Hong Kong on Sunday.

item.title: Bodies Are Found Close to Where Missing Students Clashed With Police in Mexico
item.description: The authorities found clandestine graves containing several bodies Saturday near a southern Mexico town where students at a teachers college clashed with the police a week ago.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Jean-Claude Duvalier, ‘Baby Doc’ of Haiti, Dies at 63
item.description: Mr. Duvalier succeeded his father, François, in the role they called “president for life,” and he went on to lead Haiti with a shocking brutality.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: Jean-Claude Duvalier, forefront, and his father, François Duvalier, in an undated photo.

item.title: In Ukraine, Civilians in Crossfire
item.description: Civilian casualties have soared as separatist rebels with heavy artillery attack the airport in Donetsk and Ukrainian forces respond with often ill-directed fire.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Once a Draw, Restive Region in China Suffers After Unrest
item.description: After reports of rioting, terrorism and deadly police shootings, tourism has plummeted in Xinjiang, long considered one of China’s most exotic destinations.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kanas Lake has been popular with tourists, but reports of terrorism have caused numbers to dip.

item.title: Shabab Fighters Pull Out of a Somali Stronghold as Government Troops Advance
item.description: Hundreds of civilians also fled the coastal town of Barawe in fear they would be caught in crossfire as Somali and African Union troops approached.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMED IBRAHIM

item.title: With Robust Economy, Poland Navigates Around Eastern Europe’s Strains
item.description: With Russia again seeking to exert its influence and much of Europe struggling to recover fully from the deep downturn of recent years, Poland has become a leading symbol of stability.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: A giant new Amazon distribution center is opening outside Poznan, in western Poland.

item.title: Rebels in Eastern Ukraine Dream of Reviving Soviet Heyday
item.description: In the relative lull of a cease-fire, separatist leaders have set about building neo-Soviet states like those created in other pro-Russian enclaves.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rebel commander, right, directed artillery fire with his unit from a building near the Donetsk airport, in eastern Ukraine. The fight between the pro-Russian rebels and Ukrainian government forces for the strategically important airport has intensified in recent days, despite a Sept. 5 cease-fire agreement.

item.title: In New Front Against Islamic State, the Dictionary Becomes a Weapon
item.description: Muslim groups in Europe and beyond are lashing out at the Islamic State in protests and on social media, advocating alternative ways to refer to the militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Biden Apologizes to Turkish President
item.description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. apologized to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan for remarks suggesting that Turkey helped facilitate the rise of the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: In Golan, Imagined Risks Become All Too Real
item.description: The Golan Heights, long Israel’s quietest frontier, is now one of its most unpredictable, and residents are training to handle the worst.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Hong Kong Leader’s Warning Renews Protesters’ Zeal as Crowds Swell
item.description: Tens of thousands gathered outside the government headquarters after the territory’s leader said “all actions necessary” would be taken to allow government workers to return to work.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Protesters scuffling on Saturday with a man trying to remove a barricade in Mong Kok. The police said eight of the 19 men arrested over violence had gang ties.

item.title: Indian State in Mourning After Graft Conviction
item.description: In a country that has long tolerated brazen corruption in its leaders, tears of despair and suicides followed the sentencing of the Tamil Nadu chief minister, Jayalalithaa Jayaram.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Jayalalithaa Jayaram, the chief minister of Tamil Nadu, was sentenced to four years in prison.

item.title: Fighting on Multiple Fronts in Syria
item.description: As fighting continued across the country, President Bashar al-Assad made a rare public appearance, joining prayers for the Eid al-Adha holiday at a mosque in Damascus.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Russia Cancels Exchange Program After a Student Seeks U.S. Asylum
item.description: Russian media reported that the student feared returning to Russia because he could face persecution over his sexuality.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Scrutinized for Handling of Protests, Police Have Own Troubles
item.description: Police officers in Hong Kong spoke of their frustration at bearing the brunt of protesters’ anger, and at having their hands tied by government policy.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Officers separated an injured man from the crowd Saturday after scuffles in the Mong Kok area.

item.title: Ebola’s Cultural Casualty: Hugs in Hands-On Liberia
item.description: As Ebola ravages West Africa, Liberians are losing an integral part of their culture, in which the double-cheek kiss was once the standard greeting.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Sunday service at Bridgeway Baptist Church in Monrovia, Liberia, where Ebola has upset an integral part of the culture.

item.title: South and North Korea Agree to New Talks
item.description: A breakthrough appeared to come Saturday, during a meeting between South Korean officials and a delegation from the North visiting for the closing ceremony of the Asian Games.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Kim Kwan-jin, left, the top national security adviser for President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, met Hwang Pyong-so, second from right, the top political officer of the North Korean military, and other top officials from the North in Incheon on Saturday. It was the highest-level talks in years, fueling hopes of a breakthrough in the nations’ troubled ties.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Triad Links to Attack on Protesters Raise Some Old Questions
item.description: Pro-democracy protesters have accused Hong Kong law enforcement of cooperating with shadowy criminals at the behest of Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Color Revolution’ in China a ‘Daydream,’ People’s Daily Tells Protesters
item.description: In its third commentary in three days on the Hong Kong protests, the Chinese Communist Party mouthpiece warned Saturday of “turmoil” if the rule of law is not respected.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: In Unusual Trip, North Korean Aides Attend Games in South
item.description: Three trusted aides to the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un arrived in South Korea on Saturday to attend the closing ceremony of the Asian Games in a highly unusual trip.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
